Award.AbstractNarration: With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Kirshenbaum at New York University is studying a family of “peptoid” molecules that mimic natural proteins. Peptoids are peptide-mimics but with the side chain connected to the nitrogen of the peptide backbone. Because this unique backbone structure, they often are more stable in biological systems and can be used for therapeutic applications. Professor Kirshenbaum's project explores how organizing the peptoids into cyclic structures may enable the design of new molecules with elaborate structures and valuable functions. The broader impacts of the project include collaborations with researchers on the chemical biology of cancer and creation of intellectual property for commercial development of bioactive peptidomimetics. Students contributing to the project are trained at the interface of bio-organic chemistry and biomedicine. Professor Kirshenbaum provides valuable training for a broad range of students including a project suitable for high school students. Professor Kirshenbaum makes TV appearances and appears in social media that informs the general public about the properties and functions of biological molecules. <br/> <br/>Peptoids are peptidomimetic oligomers composed of N-substituted glycine units. A variety of biomimetic properties have recently been described for peptoids. In order to further develop functional peptoids, the project is pursuing new strategies to enforce their conformational ordering. The research establish predictable relationships between the sequence, the structure, and the function of peptoid oligomers. In particular, the project explores the use of macrocyclic constraints to dictate the folding of peptoids for diverse applications. These applications include complex metal-associated, self-assembling materials and peptoid macrocycles to antagonize protein-protein interactions of biomedical importance. Establishing improved computational strategies for prediction of peptoid macrocycle structures is a critical component of the research plan. Teaching modules introduce peptidomimetic enzyme inhibitors to undergraduate biochemistry laboratory classes.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has led to a set of outcomes that have sucessfully advanced our efforts in biomimetic chemistry. We explored a family of promising synthetic chain molecules called peptoids that resemble the characteristics of the peptides and proteins that are essential for all living systems. Peptoids are composed of a specific sequence of diverse chemical building blocks. The information encoded in these sequences establishes their capability to fold, similar to the self-organization of folded proteins. Our previous work identified some preliminary guidelines to direct the formation of rudimentary peptoid structural features. But the discovery of peptoids with sophisticated materials properties and biological functions will require an enhanced ability to design particular folded forms. This project explored the premise that cyclic versions of peptoid molecules may be constrained to adopt predictable ordered conformations. During the award period, we succesfully demonstrated that cyclic peptoids exhibit enhanced conformational ordering and we established corresponding design principles for peptoids that we communicated to the scientific community. 

Intellectual Merit

Throughout the project period, we studied the relationship between the sequences, the strucures and the functions of cylic peptoids. We identified cyclic peptoids that mimic the chemical attributes and biological activity of antimicrobial petides found in nature. These synthetic oligomers exbhibited a remarkable ability to combat the replication of a broad range of viral pathogens. Because of their significant therapeutic potential, our results garnered global attention in the popular press. We also reported on other peptoid molecules that potently block the growth of prostate cancer tumors. In order to enable the discovery of other peptoids to solve a vast range of needs, we created a general design strategy. We developed a computational method to identify which cyclic peptoids are most likely to be conformationally ordered. We created a data bank of experimentally determined peptoid structures and provided an overview of how to use this information to direct future designs. These significant outcomes, along with additional studies during the project period, have created a pathway for discovery of synthetic molecules inspired by nature. 

Broader Impacts:

We conducted a set of activities consistent with the broader impacts criteria articulated by the NSF. In particular, we conducted extensive training of young scientists and the transfer of technology to the commercial sector. Our NSF award provided robust oppotunities to guide students towards future accomplishments in bioorganic chemistry. Our trainees ranged from freshmen undergrads through PhD students. One high school student contributed to the NSF project and was the co-author of an article on peptoid computational design. We were also activelty engaged in the transfer of the new technologies that we developed to industry. We worked with a corporate partner to commercialize our new peptoid antiviral molecules to avert future pandemic threats.
